Purpose
The purpose of this guideline is for ultrasound staff to know what procedures to follow when placenta praevia or vasa praevia or placenta accreta are suspected in the asymptomatic patient.
Equality and Diversity
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
The Equality Impact Assessment Form (EIA) form has been compiled see Appendix C.
Background
The morbidity and mortality from placenta praevia and placenta accreta are considerable in both the mother and the fetus and are associated with increased demands on health resources.
Unlike placenta praevia, vasa praevia carries no major maternal risk but is associated with significant risk to the fetus.

The relationship of the leading edge of the placenta to the internal os is determined by ultrasonic techniques and management decisions for patients with placenta praevia and vasa praevia are based on clinical and ultrasound findings.
Consistent management of placenta praevia and vasa praevia make it easier to counsel patients and their partners and reduces their anxiety levels after the initial diagnosis.
Scope of Practice
This protocol covers patients who are suspected of having a low-lying placenta, vasa praevia, or vasa accreta. This protocol only covers patients who are asymptomatic.
Patients who are bleeding and who are suspected of having a low-lying placenta or vasa praevia should be managed individually according to their needs.
Definition of Placenta Praevia
Placenta praevia exists when the placenta is located in the lower segment of the uterus as follows:
A major praevia describes a placenta that overlaps or covers the internal os
A minor praevia exists when the placenta reaches the internal os
Ultrasound Protocol for Initial Diagnosis of Placenta Praevia

If the placenta is thought to be low at the 18-20 week anatomy a transvaginal scan should be performed using colour flow Doppler. When a transvaginal scan is required a chaperone must be present regardless of the gender of the person performing the examination as per the hospital chaperone policy (05118).

If the placenta is thought to be low lying (less than  mm from the internal os) or praevia (covering the os) at the routine fetal anomaly scan, a follow-up ultrasound examination (+/- a TVS) is recommended at 32 weeks of gestation to diagnose persistent low-lying placenta and/or placenta praevia.
The patient should be given a patient information leaflet about placenta praevia.
Antenatal Management Protocol for Placenta Praevia
The follow-up scan should be booked on the relevant clinician's clinic day so that problems may be discussed with the obstetric registrar or consultant on call if necessary.
A trans-abdominal scan should be performed initially to measure fetal growth.

For the third trimester ultrasound scan in patients where the leading edge of the placenta is difficult to locate or appears low, a transvaginal scan should be performed; having obtained prior verbal consent from the patient. The obstetric registrar or consultant on call should be contacted before attempting a transvaginal scan in the presence of active bleeding to ensure that it is safe to do so.
Where relevant, the following should be recorded on the patient administration computer system (PACS) system and quoted in the report:
The distance of the placental edge to the internal os
The thickness of the leading edge if seen to be bulky
The relationship of the fetal head to the leading edge

Where the placenta is low, document placental lakes or a history of any uterine surgery i.e. myomectomy or caesarean and where the placenta is in relation to the scar i.e. underlying the scar or clear of the scar.
If there is evidence of vasa praevia
Fetal measurements to include head circumference (HC), abdominal circumference (AC) and femur length (FL)
A comment on the level of amniotic fluid present according to the gestational age
Estimation of fetal weight with the margin of error quoted

In cases where the measurement from the leading edge of the placenta to the internal os is 2.5cm or less, a repeat scan should be booked for  weeks. The patient should also be referred to the Antenatal Clinic for discussion with their obstetrician consultant.
Definition of Vasa Praevia

Vasa praevia describes fetal vessels coursing through the membranes over the internal cervical os and below the fetal presenting part, unprotected by placental tissue or the umbilical cord. This can be secondary to a velamentous cord insertion in a single or bi-lobed placenta or from fetal vessels running between lobes of a placenta with one or more accessory lobes (succenturiate lobes).
Ultrasound Protocol for Initial Diagnosis and Management of Vasa Praevia (Refer to Appendix A)
If a succenturiate lobe is identified at the 18-20 week anatomy scan or vasa praevia is suspected a trans-vaginal scan should be performed using colour flow Doppler to observe for vasa praevia.

Following TVS, if vasa praevia is evident, the patient should be referred to the fetal medicine specialist. In the absence of the specialist, the patient should be seen by the patient's named consultant at the next available appointment.
(Refer to point  for details of how the scan findings should be recorded)
Definition of Placenta Accreta

A morbidly adherent placenta includes placenta accreta, increta and percreta as it penetrates through the decidua basalis into and then through the myometrium, but for ease of description the term accreta will be used in this guideline as a general term for all of these conditions.
Patients with a previous caesarean section require a higher index of suspicion as there are two problems to exclude: placenta praevia and placenta accreta.
Ultrasound Protocol for Initial Diagnosis or Placenta Praevia Accreta
If the placenta is thought to be low at the 18-20 week anatomy scan a trans-vaginal scan should be performed using colour flow Doppler.

Following TVS if the placenta measures less than 20mm from, reaches, overlaps or covers the cervix (minor or major praevia) a follow-up scan at 32 weeks gestation should be booked to assess placental position and to identify its position in relation to the caesarean scar.
Antenatal Management Protocol at  Weeks Gestation where Placenta Accreta is Suspected
In cases where the anterior placenta is underlying a caesarean scar or if placenta accreta is suspected the patient should be referred to the Antenatal Clinic for further discussion.
(Refer to point 7.4 for details of how the scan findings should be recorded)
Staff and Training

The procedures should be carried out by suitably qualified sonographers and/or obstetricians, possessing the Diploma in Medical Ultrasound (DMU), a Postgraduate Diploma in Medical Ultrasound (PG Dip) or equivalent. Ultrasound students may carry out ultrasound scans under the supervision of a qualified sonographer.
Infection Prevention

All staff should follow the Trust's guideline on infection prevention paying particular attention to the specific ultrasound protocols relating to the cleaning of ultrasound equipment. (Refer to Appendix B)
Audit and Monitoring
Compliance with the guideline is monitored as part of the ultrasound department audit process, the results of which are disseminated to all staff concerned on a regular basis.
Communication with Patients
Following the ultrasound scan, patients are given a verbal report and a written copy of the report to take home with them on the day of their scan.
The patient should be given a patient information leaflet about placenta praevia.
Communication and Implementation
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Staff Focus that is sent via email to all staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff via email.
The latest revised guidelines can be accessed via the intranet and clinical guideline folders in each ultrasound room.

Appendix A
Ultrasound Department Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust
Infection control procedure for the decontamination of Ultrasound Transducers. For intra-cavity and non-intra-cavity procedures.
Prior to vaginal ultrasound examinations
Ensure the patient is comfortable and relaxed.
Explain the procedure to the patient.
Obtain verbal/written consent from the patient for this procedure.
Confirmation of consent should be documented in the written report or in the patient's notes.
A Chaperone must be present throughout the scan, as per Trust chaperone policy.
If possible lock the door to maintain privacy.
Screen the patient to protect privacy while undressing – using the ceiling mounted curtain or mobile screen.
No one should enter the room, whilst the examination is undertaken.
Equipment
The equipment must be thoroughly cleaned prior to use and decontaminated after use and this should be documented in the written report or patient's notes.
The operators' hands must be washed and/or decontaminated with alcohol gel hand rub both before and after the scan.
Procedure – intra-cavity ultrasound
Examination gloves must be worn when carrying out the scan.
Apply a small amount of gel in the teat of the cover.
Cover the inter-cavity transducer with an ultrasound probe cover (all covers are single use only). Document whether latex or non-latex probe cover is used in the written report or patient's notes.
Use a non-spermicidal probe cover for infertility patients.
Use a latex free probe cover for patients with a latex allergy.
A single use sachet of lubricating gel is to be applied to the end of the inter-cavity transducer.
Undertake the procedure.
Procedure – Non intra-cavity ultrasound
Apply a small amount of gel to the surface of the transducer.
Undertake procedure.
Appendix B
Decontamination of Equipment after each Procedure

table_items.text: Remove excess gel with a paper tissue
Remove excess gel with a paper tissue

Clean and decontaminate the intra-cavity transducer and cable with a detergent wipe* by: (i) (ii) Covering the surface and sides of the transducer with the detergent wipe Rotate and progress the wipe along the length of the cable. (iii) This step should be repeated with a fresh wipe until the transducer and cable are visibly clean.
Clean all surfaces of the transducer and cable with a detergent wipe*.

Next decontaminate the transducer using Tristel Duo by: (i) Depress the pump once to dispense Duo Foam onto the surface. (ii) Use a paper towel and spread evenly. (iii) Ensure all areas of the surface come into contact with foam. (iv) Leave to dry, allow 30 seconds before contact.
Dry the transducer with a paper tissue
The non-intracavity transducer is now ready for the next patient
*Detergent wipes = Clinell Multi Surface Detergent Wipes
